reviewText:
Microsoft: Hey Telltales we need a game based on minecraft.
Telltales: Not now Microsoft we're busy.
Microsoft *adds a 0 on the check*
Telltales: Ok we'll get our team to start thinking of the plot.
Microsoft *adds another 0*
Telltales: Ok we will finish the beta prototype this week.
Microsoft: *adds another 0*
Telltales: Ok we just finished the trailer for the game and it will go live in 30 minutes.

The point of this review was to illustrate how rushed the game felt like and how money can be the major factor on how well the game was developed.

A lot of degenerate low mental capacity 5 year-old fanboys have been commenting hate on this review, well ♥♥♥♥ off cause its just a opinion you dysfunctional turds.

reviewText:
A sub-par Telltale title...

But why you may ask? It is simple the game is filled with references to Minecraft, but that’s not the bad part. The bad part is that’s all it is, references there is no substance no engaging story no real narrative or characters you care about.

The first 30 minutes of the game is a brutal slog of uninspired writing and weak character building, comparatively to other Telltale titles.  The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, Tales From The Borderlands, and Game of Thrones are all vastly superior in the quality of characters, writing, and player engagement.

To expand on characters here is a list...
The Pig
The Fat Guy
The Girl
The Cool Girl
The Tunnel Snakes
The Nice Tunnel Snake
Lee EverettThe characters are bland and are given no real distinct or likable traits, making them unmemorable (see list) and near pointless to the story other than bouncing dialog off of.

I purchased this game assuming that it would have the same quality that Telltale always delivers, but it did not. I have refunded my copy and a copy I gifted to a friend (On his request because its controls were broken). Hopefully this is not a sign that all future Telltale titles will become uninspired cash grabs but only time will tell.

reviewText:
Minecraft: Story Mode doesn’t feel like a Telltales game. It feels like a cash-in. It feels like Microsoft threw a big beefy contract at Telltales and said “Just do the usual”.

At first glance it may look like the usual fare: an impressive ensemble cast and a heavy lean on comedy but in actuality they've taken some big names, thrown them into a mixing bowl and hoped for the best.

Some of the Actors are dreadful and either don’t understand voice acting or have had terrible direction. The plot - or as much as I absorbed - isn’t very interesting.

In a lot of ways it’s similar to existing Telltales games but instead of an engrossing story with memorable characters it’s a waste of effort on the developer's part and a waste of time on the player’s.

reviewText:
I am a Telltale games aholic and when I saw this game I had a bad feeling about it. Because minecraft seemed like possible the worst IP to make a story based game around. However, I decided to give it a chance as so far Telltales borderlands which I also thought was a bad IP for telltale so far has been done surprsingly well. However my fears were confirmed this time. This is by far the worst Telltale game made yet and has so far and is bad enough to be a embarissment to their company. This game compared to all the other IPs they have purchesed in the past is the most obvious cash grab and Telltale was unfortnatlly not able to make the IP work with their game play style this time.

There are many negatives about this game...
1. It has a very bland and predictable story line and charcters. In other games this would not be that big a deal however since telltale games are entierly story driven this really is a huge deal breaker.

2. You have much less controll over what your charcter does and what they say than other telltale games. You will see obvious traps ahead and want to prevent them but will have no means to do so or wish for your charecter to do or say something different and not have the option to do it much more often than any other telltale game.  I understand that most telltale choices are only giving you a veil of choice however the veil in this game is way to easy to see through.

3. The few big choices the game lets you make that actually make a bit of a difference are much easier and unimportant than the other telltale games. They do not make you have the feeling of regreting your choice as the other IPs have. Nor do they have me think about what choice to make and the possible consquences for at least a good 5 minates like some of the other IPs often do as the choices are not only easier but also seem less important.

4. The game makes occsional minor mistakes in which skin for differnet items you should have forgetting your past choices which if followed you should have a different skin for that item.

Currnetly I would only recommend this game under 2 conditions.

#1 You are one of the young zeolous minecraft fanatics and love anything that has anything to do with minecraft in which case you already purchased the game anyway so your pretty much only reading negative comments to defend it.

#2 You are like me a telltale junkie and have already purchased all the other telltale games including similar games that are not telltale like life is strange and are desperate as hell waiting for more, have good amount of free time and disposable income. Even if that is the case I would recommend waiting for this to go on sale. I understand the need for telltales games crack but this is some low quality stuff that will barely keep you content.
voteText: 755 of 1,175 people (64%) found this review helpful 41 people found this review funny

reviewText:
All the kid-friendly fun of Minecraft with none of the creativity that makes it unique.

While I've been a big fan of Telltale Games in the past, this game lacks the depth and intensity of its predecessors. Perhaps I shouldn't have been surprised... it's Minecraft, after all. Of course it's going to be extremely kid friendly with flat characters and juvenile scripting. Yet it was abundantly obvious to me that this title is Telltale Games' attempt to reach a younger demographic by playing upon a recognizable brand. Telltale will probably make a lot of money on this title, but no one is going to remember it.

This game could be a lot of fun for young gamers (14 and under). For anyone older, I can't recommend the purchase.

reviewText:
Played season 1 through 2 times. Many choices lead to same outcome and don't change character's opinions. Is great if you want a story, but outcome is very restricted whether you mess up or not. I like the game, however the choices lack depth and allow you to go through with random choices, without much punishment. For a game based on choices, I honestly feel disrespected as I consider myself a smart person, although I am treated as if I am not able to intellectually handle a concept based game.
5 USD an episode with a startup game cost of an additional 20 USD is just not worth it to me.

Upon further review, my knowledge of the price of the game was based on speculation and lack of research. The price is reasonable at 5 USD an episode flat. my review of everything else however doesn't change

reviewText:
Not terribly sure what to think of it yet. Definitely feels like a Telltale game for the younger generation.
If you pick this up, don't be expecting Game of thrones or TWD quality of jump-scares and intensity. It's very basic; obviously not geared towards the older PC players out there.

Interesting concept, but for now I have to say it was a little lacking compared to other Telltale games I've played. This is probably due to the immaturity of the feel to the game rather than anything else.

I don't care about the characters yet - but I look forwards to seeing what happens in the next few episodes.

Recommended for younger players, as well as people who enjoy Minecraft.. immensely.
Not recommended for those who wish to have a more serious approach to their gaming experience. If you want meaningful choices and intense quick-time events then play another of Telltale's games; not this one.

This review is taking into consideration only the first episode of the game.

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review by telling you guys how happy I am that this game was SO much better than what I expected.

Lot of people gave this game sh*t because it was way different from what we've gotten used to seeing from Telltale Games, and simply because it was based on Minecraft.

For whatever reason, people assume Minecraft is a game for young audiences who have very little understanding about videogames. But I beg to differ, I personally think Minecraft is suitable for all ages. For anyone who wants to have a game where they can explore a world full of mysteries, where they can put their creativity to work.

You guys have no idea how many messages I got from people saying like ehhrmageerrdd you're playing Minecraft what are you
date: 10 years old???" as I was playing this game..\nThe point I'm trying to make is that
recommended: people tend to have misconceptions about Minecraft itself just because it's known for having somewhat cancerous fanbase filled with immature kids. It's kind of sad that this is why people aren't interested in it because Minecraft: Story Mode is a fantastic and fresh experience from Telltale Games.\n\nSo many people were sh*tting on this game before the first episode had even launched just for the sake of it being a Minecraft game. And you know what? I thank those people for giving me the wrong idea of this game

reviewText:
I'm indifferent on Minecraft: Story Mode so far... I mean, I like Minecraft I suppose. But I'm not a hardcore fanboy. I am however a huge fanboy for Telltale games. However this game feels way off the beaten path from Telltale's engaging style, and feels more like playing through a Saturday morning cartoon.

I would caution the seasoned Telltale player that if you're looking for a deep, engaging story, that pulls at your heart and makes you deal with some serious tragedy and strife, that this is not at all your game.

However if you're a fan of Minecraft and want a more casual, lighthearted story, this might be for you. But just from what I've dealved into thus far, I don't think it's for me.

I'll play through the entire thing as it comes out because I owe the game that, but this isn't quite what I expected from Telltale. Not that I'm sure what I expected.. I guess I just didn't think Telltale would ever put their name on something like this.. It's so far from everything they've ever done.

I hate to use the term but, I think this is what selling out looks like.
voteText: 275 of 474 people (58%) found this review helpful 11 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Minecraft: Story Mode
I'm very dissappointed. First of all, I haven't played episode four. Not gonna play it anyway, so I don't care anymore. At first I was hopeful about this game. I knew it wouldn't have the dark tone of the other telltale games but still I looked forward to it, and just now, I realize I was wrong. I won't even bother to mention the language problems with it. If you're not an english speaker, don't even bother to get this game. If you choose another language that's not english, the game will choose another language which is not the one you chose.

Now that I got that off my chest, I'll say my real problem with this game. I don't care about any of the characters, the only character that grew into me sightly is Ivor and he's not even that of a major character. All of them are plain and stereothyped in my opinion, and you know what? maybe I'm wrong, but that's what I feel. Why am I supposed to care about all these people?

The story is just... nothing. It's cliche, I can't tell how many times I've seen a story like this in movies, books and other games. I know this game is supposed to be for all ages, so the story can't be dark, but I don't ask for a dark story, I ask for an interesting one.  Don't get me wrong, a story can contain cliches, but it also needs original stuff to make it something different, and this is what Minecraft: SM doesn't have. It gives nothing new to the industry nor the players.

Choices may matter a bit, yeah, but at what cost? If the story is bad, I don't care if the choices matter or not. I'm dissappointed, and I was wrong when I was hopeful about this game. I mean no offense to the people who liked it, but I didn't. It doesn't have a good story, it doesn't have interesting characters, the graphics are bad, the gameplay is non existant. And yes, I know Telltale games have non existant gameplay, but at the same time, those telltale games at least have an interesting story, so the lack of gameplay isn't noticeable. In MCSM it is noticeable because the story is awful. If it doesn't have a good story, at least it should have something else to like. What am I supposed to like about this game?

reviewText:
This game is kind of about your own tastes. I mean, I had a lot of fun. But here's the thing; if you want an exact copy of Minecraft but with a story, sorry buddy, you ain't getting it.
Minecraft story mode doesn't let you freely build or do whatever you want when you want. What it does do, is tells a story about friends who take it upon themselves to save Minecraftia (or whatever.) About 70% of the game is cutscenes with choices. Like a movie! The other 30 percent you're battling the naraduels of the Nether or the night. Or, even crafting.
Some people say that they didn't do a good enough time to develop characters. True, they jumped right into the story. But around the end of the first episode, I felt a bit of a bond between Jesse, Olivia, Lukas, Axel, Reuben, and Petra. The characters are likeable, (except for Axel at times)
Oh my God, and when you get into the episodes further, I felt such a bond between the characters. If something happened to them that I could have changed, I would feel so guilty.
This game is worth the money.

reviewText:
The Good
I thought this game was very well developed. You can see that the universe is implemented very well into the game. There are a few knicks here and there the game was overall pretty much like Minecraft.

The style/system the game was developed on is a pretty common system that you can find on many games. Walk around and click what you'd like to interact with. I'm not very familiar with Telltale games but I am familiar with quite a few general titles.

The storyline at some points were predictable but overall has a nice plot and I can't wait to see the next episodes. I can already see many people foreshadowing different episodes and stuff.

The Bad
This game became very over-hyped with all its advertisements. It did look like an exciting game with a different style to it, but the game was almost too basic. It might just be me, but I felt that this Episode was absolutely short. Like I said, I'm not too familiar with Telltale games so whether or not they keep their games this short, it is not really worth the $22.50-$25.

Though the story was quite interesting and the choices you can make help develop the game, the playtime is rather short. Most of the story is watching the story and making choices. There isn't much walking around or fighting mobs.

At some points in the story, it seemed almost predictable. I understand the game audience may not be people 18 and older, but if you're gonna play any game the excitement draws from the astonishment.

Conclusion
This game was indeed fun and does have a very interesting story. Sadly, the game was very short and did not have much play time. I completed this game in a few hours. It could have been faster but you can't skip the cutscenes.

Overall, this game is fun. BUT I do not believe it is worth the money. Telltale seemed to have created this because Minecraft is such a popular title and they saw the potential cash grab.

Nevertheless, if you would like to play this game, be my guest. It was fun and interesting and well worth the few hours I spent on it. But if you have been contemplating on the price of this game with its worth, I would suggest not. $25 is not worth it.

reviewText:
FOR BOTH EPISODES SO FAR

I had high hopes for this game, but it unfortunately came up short. It follows the traditional Telltale recipe of an interactive movie, but feels a little bit forced.

PROS
It's a Minecraft game
Great soundtrack
Devs that seem to have a decent sense of humor
CONS
It doesn't really feel like a Minecraft game. For one thing, it does that 90's adventure game thing where the environments are one fixed screen that your character has to move around in, which really doesn't lend itself to the sandbox atmosphere of Minecraft.
Quick time events. Everything you do that doesn't involve moving the mouse is a quick time event. They really could have been more creative.
UGH THE CAMERA (See bullet point number 1)
The puzzles are to easy and too few. In the first episode, for example, there are only TWO PUZZLES. One of the puzzles, you just have to talk to someone, and the other is so easy to figure out that I accidentally solved it while trying to figure out what the puzzle even was.
They try (unsuccessfully) to work crafting into the game. The interface is clunky (right clicking, dragging, and all of that smooth Minecraft stuff won't work) and you can only make very limited things at very specific times. In fact, crafting is only used three times in the first episode, and it's only when it's necessary to move the story forward.
Shallow characters. The biggest thing about a story-based game is the character development, which simply does not exist in this game. The only interesting character in the entire game is Reuben the Pig. All of the other characters are simply archetypes and nothing else.
Five minutes of credits at the end.
The opening credits don't start until the end of Chapter 1.
The story doesn't make sense. SPOILER: Ivor has the same goal as you -- stopping the Wtiherstorm and saving the world. But the whole time, he is trying to stop you as well, something that makes no sense whatsoever.
And on top of all that, it doesn't even have trading cards.

reviewText:
Having never played a Telltale game before, I wasn't exactly sure what to expect going into it. I am a Minecraft fan so the concept and trailers were appealing to me, and I picked it up on sale figuring it would be a decent buy.
The game is not at all what I was expecting. Interaction is minimal, I would hardly even call it a game. There's no skill involved, other than pressing arrow keys at correct times when it flashes on your screen. Most of the choices for the player come in the form of dialogue options, but none seem to have much of an impact on the game. The only significant story impacting choice I've found is choosing which hero to rescue at the end of Chapter 1. When you actually get to control your character's movement, its rather pointless, as there's only one path to go on 90% of the time anyways. The combat in the game is extremely dull, The game feels a bit short too, took me 5 hours for a playthrough of the current four episodes.

If this is what all Telltale games are like, then to each their own, but personally, I'd recommend just watching someone else do a playthrough if you want to see the story rather than spending your own money on it.

reviewText:
As much as it pains me to say bad things about A) Telltale and B) Minecraft, I just have to. This game could have been one of the greatest creations in computing history, what with two of the most popular gaming names behind it. It failed. Unlike in Telltale's Game of Thrones, where I can never wait for the next chapter and play it all the way through the day it comes out, and unlike in Minecraft, where there's always something else to do even in Vanilla, this game has neither aspect. Although it does have an interesting storyline for a non-storyline-based game, the characters are rather cliche and boring, it's extremely child-friendly with none of the tension or emotions of Telltale's previous successes and they have ruined the greates (in my opinion) enemy a sandbox game has ever seen (More later).

I'll start on the animation. Although this game is based off of something with no communication or cutscene programming whatsoever, this game is probably better off to keep it that way. The animations seem too cartoony for a supposedly dramatic storyline and it ruins the atmosphere. The mouths ingame are too simplistic and are more like something you would find in a very old, very amateur, Windows '95 era game with only different mouth shapes for each sound.

Secondly, the characters. [Spoiler Alert] You have the cliche main character=leader, brutish-looking guy is intimidating but a bit dim and actually soft on the inside, the girl is intelligent and usually/always knows the best thing to do (even if everyone ignores her), the badass side character who comes in to save the day and becomes a main character, and the bully who learns his lesson and makes friends with the main character. This makes them very predictable and extremely boring.

Thirdly, the villain/enemy/boss, whatever you want to call it. [Spoiler Alert] The Wither is supposed to be an extremely powerful, 3-headed, flying creature, which I grant, it is. It does NOT, however, consume anything to evolve and grow. The Wither Telltale have given us here, to put simply, looks ridiculous. Just the look of it ruins the whole idea of it in actual Minecraft. It looks silly, and overdone, and nothing like the Wither at all. It does not have tentacles that reach out and grab people and blocks, it is supposed to throw a toxic-like ball at the people of Minecraftia with the destruction of blocks being collateral damage. This monstrosity (the bad context) is an insult to the Wither I, and maybe we, have come to know and fear.

All in all, this game had huge potential and I was extremely excited to see what they would do, and hugely disappointed. The game is the worst it could have been, with all the negative aspects of each Telltale and Minecraft, not the greatness within each. I shall complete it, but only because I don't like leaving anything unfinished, even this, and, as said, the storyline is, albeit only just, decent.


Thanks for reading. Sorry there's so much.

reviewText:
As of the time I'm writing this review, only one episode is out. Episode 2-5 will come in the months to follow. Depending on if people are reading this review, expect an update by then.

Alright guys, let's get this over with before you keep on reading.
This is not a game where you can run around freely.
This is not a game where you can build your own buildings.
This is not a game where you survive.

It's not like Minecraft.

Don't expect an experience you had while playing Minecraft. This is a whole different kind of game.
But is it bad?

Short answer: No, definitely not.

You might not be familiar with TellTale games. If that's the case, then allow me to briefly explain what you can expect here. Like the name suggests, this game tells a tale. It is as if you're watching a movie, but with you as the main character. You're watching, meaning for the majority of the time, you're sitting back and watching the story unfold. But at the same time, you're the main character. That means you'll be able to talk for the main character, and sometimes play short scenes with him. But that's it. Now if this is your first TellTale game, then this might sound weird, and not very fun.

Alright, if you're familiar with TellTale, then start reading here, because this is where the 'tale' part comes in. In the beginning of the review I told you it's not like Minecraft. Or at least, it doesn't deliver an experience you might expect from a Minecraft game. Like I said, there's no building. No surviving. No exploring... But there's a tale. As this game's title suggests, it's a 'Story Mode'. A tale in the Minecraft universe. And believe me when I say, the tale is great. Sure, it's not for everyone, but as someone who has played lots of Minecraft in the past, I can say it really fits in the game's universe, and the story itself is also really well made. I'm being careful not to spoil anything here though, so I'll have to stop there.

If you need a more detailed review on the story itself, then check out other reviews on this game. My goal was to warn" you that this game might not be what you think it is."

reviewText:
My review is one that may be worth your time reading. The reason I say that is because I am not a massive Minecraft enthusiast nor am I someone that dislikes the game. I'm just an individual who loves playing games and reviewing them, if the games good i'll like it but if it is not I won't. Therefore my stance is completely unbiased going into this game. This is also my first experience with TellTale which is rather new for me. I will update my post when every new episode comes out.

EPISODE 1:
The game surprised me with its focus that was primarily on voice actors and cutscenes, Both of which were absolutely outstanding. The voice acting cast for this game was talented and the effort put into every line of dialogue was full of impact. Cut scenes were graphically impressive and held a consistent frame rate, I found the lack of gameplay to be surprising though. The gameplay was most comparable to The Order:1886, sometimes it only took for you to walk from one end of a hall way to another to finish your section and then proceed to watch another 5-10 minutes of cutscenes.

The game is mostly a point and click adventure with a bit of walking, making choices and clicking on things is all you do for the most part. The choice making is very much like Until Dawn in that what you say will effect the people around you and what you do will possibly change the whole scenario for the worse. This was incredibly effective and one of the first games ive ever played where I felt my choices actually mattered compared to games like Life Is Strange or Until Dawn where sometimes you would tell the charector to do one thing and then they'd end up doing the other anyway.

Overall as a game that played out as more of a rather interactive movie rather than a video game it was quite good. If you just want to sit back and enjoy yourself this is worth your money BUT I must address the one major con to the game that goes out of it's way to beat you over the head which was the button mashing (quick time events). The placing for quick time events were frequent but incredibly awkward which sometimes lead you to cheap deaths.

Instead of hitting, collecting and creating houses and forts to live in you just bashed the Q" button and watched the players do it themselves which was a real head scratcher concidering the franchise. I almost feel that the term "Minecraft: Story Mode" was not appropriate for this game
date: just because it would have been better off as a spin off game (and gotten way much less hate)\n\nConclusion: Effective choices
hoursPlayed: a compelling story
voteText:
AMAZING voice actors but absolutely awful choices were made in regards to quick time events and taking the core element of the original games gameplay entirely out of this experience.

Episode 2:

I've been reluctant to continue doing these reviews because an obnoxious young minority who haven't even played the game have been very persistant in knocking down anything good said about this title because it is seemingly different to what they expected. I am doing them though so people don't get misinformed.

This episode homed right in on character development and also introduced a few new notable plot points but overall didnt progress the story as much as it could've. Once again the game runs beautifully and the voice acting is outstanding. This game reeled in some of the best voice actors in the industry and the pay off was brilliant. Props going mostly to the voice of Petra. Petra has one of the most unique and well fitted voices I've seen in a long time.

Besides the again suprisingly thorough choices and consequences aswell as bright

reviewText:
I'm not a big Minecrafter, I do get excited and play some once or twice a year. And this is the first time I've met with a Telltale product. I did not know what to expect but I could see good potential in the concept. Unfortunately it became a terrible disappointment pretty much from the first minute.

The plots are stupid, the conversations are boring. Overall the complexity of the story can make anyone above the age of 10 do self-harm after a couple of minutes. The whole flow of the game (interactive movie?) is painfully slow.

On the rare occasions when your character gets some freedom to act and not just talk crap you realise that the controls are horrible and the world is very linear. Otherwise it's just all talking and selecting your response in a timely manner. The later kills whatever immersion you may (not) have as you need to focus on picking your answer before the time is up, while the others are still talking. Speaking of which, dialog choices detemine the storyline and add dynamism to the gameplay. I can see how that could work, pity I can't force myself to replay the choices just to get a slightly different dumb version of the dialogs.

Not sure what's the intention with this product. It's not a good game as there's pretty much nothing to do in it. Action scenes require the pressing/smashing of one of the 5 control keys within given time. Not that too much action would be required, it's more about not missing those random moments - which again breaks immersion. Fights look awkward and unrealistic even in the standards of Minecraft.

It's not a good movie cause the lack of real plots and twists, at least ones that would get the attention of a 5th-grader or higher. Dialogs are poor and cheesy and everything's happening very slow. Could be al-right for kids, but the age range who could enjoy it the most may require parental guidance during some scenes.

It does not have stunning visuals... hey, it's Minecraft at its basics after all. And it does not have stunning acting either...

Overall it's some good money wasted with regrets in hindsight.

reviewText:
The Family Friendly Tales from the Borderlands.
Quick Synopsis:

Not being a Minecraft fan this game was eons away from being on my radar, but somtimes after slogging through monotonous triple A eye candy or banging my head after playing the latest insert MOBA here. I need to wind down. Minecraft: Story Mode was the perfect game to fill this niche. Conjuring a story for a game that is known for not having one can be a tall order, but with the framework that was given. Telltale really pulled out the begining of what seems to be a very charming narrative. I know guys don't crucify me, charming is a buzzword used often. But this game is it CHARMING, in all caps!

Pros: -Visuals are great, makes Mincraft feel soulful.
-Some of the best voice acting you will come across in a game. Paton Oswalts performance as Jesse is special.
-CHARMING(IKR) Narrative
-End choice will greatly affect episode 2's direction.
-Crafting things you are not supposed to make.
-Rueben is my best friend.

Cons:-Puzzles are non-exsistent.

Closing Statements:
Minecraft: Story Mode is not a perfect game nor is it flawed. For what it tries to do it does it well. A nice blend of family friendly humor with all of the Telltale decision making. With a Disney esque coming of age story also at play. As it stands, considering how these episodic games can change, I highly recommend this game to everyone who is looking for a heart warming tale of friendship and growing up while maintaining the Telltale spirit.

reviewText: For a style of game which intends to succeed solely on a player's investment into the story exclusively, it's remarkably bland and uninteresting. More often than not, you'll find yourself faced with quicktime events that offer little to no consequences for failure, dialogue options which offer no impact on the game itself, and, sometimes, choices which at the time seem like they'll influence the game reasonably only to find out the option you didn't choose gets resolved some way or another outside of your experience.\n\nYet all of this could be acceptable as a part of a game that at least offers an interesting story as the concept of Telltale Games is to have to experience a story which you can hopefully be at least mildly invested in. This fails in a herculean fashion. Characters are presented as important and deep when in reality, they are injected suddenly and unemotionally into the story while the plot itself is generic and often lazily progressed. This means that whenever you're faced with Telltale's trademark important decision" moments
date: you really don't have much to go off of emotionally making the choice meaningless and easy.\n\nEven as a children's game
recommended: this fails across the board for ham-fisted attempts at sudden and awkward humour
hoursPlayed: lack of any interesting story or character development
voteText: and an overall absence of the emotional investment present in...some...of Telltale's other games
helpfulPercent: for even games for children can still retain objective elements of entertainment. Believe me
votesHelpful: you can find somewhere else to put your money into."

reviewText:
While this game is tailored more to younger players, though that doesn't mean it's all bad. Yes, there are jokes only kids would laugh about, but there are definitely some genuinely funny moments as well.
The storyline is a bit more lighthearted than that of The Walking Dead games, too, but that's to be expected, since it's obviously a game about Minecraft. Again, this does in no way mean the story isn't compelling, since there are still interesting choices to be made and interesting characters to be met, but if you're someone who's looking for something dark and grim, this game might not be for you.
The five episodes this game consists of (so far) are roughly of average length from what I can tell; at least it doesn't feel like the storyline is rushed at any given point, which is good.

In short: Typical TellTale game, only a bit more lighthearted, though  it still manages to have an intriguing storyline. I had my fun with it despite not being part of the target audience"

reviewText: So I've played Minecraft: Story Mode Chapters 1-4 and what I have concluded is that it is a hit or miss for the most part. The reason I have a slight disliking for this game is because it doesn't truly represent Minecraft. Although it contains some staples of Minecraft such as mobs, landscape, and the nether/end, the story doesn't truly relate to Minecraft. When I think of a Minecraft story mode, I'd immediately think of an explanation to the actual game, not some random plot associated to the game for no reason. I'd have much more respect for this game if it wasn't tied to Minecraft since I did enjoy the story itself and the characters. As for the gameplay, the controls and camera angles weren't the best as they were very clunky and stiff. Sometimes there isn't enough time to read the options of what you can say in response to characters when they are talking either. Plus, there were many noticeable glitches throughout the game. Overall, the game itself was fine but I can't say it's a good game since it is supposed to resemble Minecraft but does an extremely poor job doing so. This game seems like Telltale's way of advertising their story by using a popular name such as Minecraft to market their game and trick people to buying what they would think is an add-on to Minecraft. If you're looking for a fun little game to play on a boring day, this game is for you. If you're a Minecraft fan, I don't recommend you play this game since it's not what it is claiming to be.

reviewText:
tl;dr - Buy this for your 10 year old, don't expect much otherwise.

It does pull off the Minecraft aesthetic pretty well, but that's about the only good thing I have to say about this game.
The story and the dialogue is very much from a children's book - bad guy pops up, good guy (you, the awesome hero) save the day. That's not really a problem though, since I guess that kind of story is expected out of a Minecraft game since it's kind of marketed towards kids these days. What is a problem though is the way the story is set up. Now I'm going to spoiler it up because people get salty about these things or whatever, but it doesn't really anything from the story -  Basically you have 4 episodes of the main story and then you have the 5th which is obviously a part of a different story which were announced to be episodes 6-8 on the release of said 5th episode.. Basically they sold an incomplete product as you would expect to get the full game experience WHEN YOU PAID THE FULL PRICE OF THE GAME. Also the story is very inconsistent. Like the guy you are supposed to hate suddenly becoming your best friend for no apparent reason inconsistent.

Other than that everything's as you would expect from a telltale game - essentially a FMV (movie) style game with QTEs thrown in where the story is effectively defined by your choices. Sadly in this one your choices don't really culminate much in anything, as no matter what you choose the outcome will be the same (with very minor differences that don't really matter at all). If previous Telltale games culminated with your choices playing a part in the ending, in this one the choices just kinda happens and no long matter 5-10 minutes after the choice's been made (I suppose sometimes some insignificant dialogue changes in the next episode or something).

And when playing do disable telltale's cloud saving. It has a tendency of losing save data and then syncing your old saves from before-previous session over your saves causing lost progress.

I have been eagerly anticipating what Microsoft will do with Minecraft's IP, and bought story mode to see their direction.  It is well known that both Microsoft and Minecraft are notoriously buggy, and sadly Story Mode is an inbred child.

HOWEVER bugs aside Telltale Games continues to write excellent, deep, and entertaining stories.  The game is good, but the lack of mining, crafting, and building leaves me longing to play minecraft. 6/10 - An outrageously buggy game, that doesn't leverage any aspects of Minecraft, but has a beautiful story.

reviewText:
Ok on Minecraft Story Mode so far, interaction is very poor and the controls seem slugish and glitchy. When you tell a story in a game your game can become linear, a way to counteract this is to add things along your journey such as secrets and minigames which make the game more enjoyable. Telltale completly left out everything non-linear and because of this I rate this game:

3/5 for story
0/5 for gameplay
1/5 for graphics

Don't get me wrong the idea is good, many games have succeeded using movie aspects to build a great game but the execution of actual gameplay must be present, and Telltale games failed to provide even a sliver of imersion into the game.

reviewText:
NB: This review is for episodes 1-5, as currently episodes 6-8 have been announced as purchasable DLC #ElectronicArts

Minecraft Story Mode is TellTale's latest episodic adventure in which we play as a young aspiring hero named Jesse, accompanied by a group of friends, who's mission is to reunite the long-lost Order of the Stone to help save the World. Without spoiling anything or revealing too much, the adventure takes them to various wonderous and dangerous places in order to find the lost members of the Order and defeat an evil entity. This is concluded by the end of episode 4 which felt short lived, and episode 5 is the first chapter of a new adventure for our heroes which will be continued in the DLC (sneaky plans TellTale). I was extremely excited for this game as I am a huge TellTale and Minecraft fan, but sadly I was left dissapointed. While the story was fairly well written the subtitles were not, there were even stages where the subtitles said something completely out of context while the characters were speaking. There are also some story blunders, the worst being when a character who had repeatedly caused trouble for the group returns in secret to speak to Jesse, once accepted by Jesse he is brought to the group but they all seem to have forgotten what he has done and accept him without questions or an apology. The story falters at other stages too especially in the choices: there was always a choice A and a choice B but then also a choice C which was practically choice A and B combined, and the obvious best choice. This is just plain lazy and not what should be expected and accpeted from TellTale. Their games are supposed to make me value my choices and think clearly before I decide, Minecraft Story Mode failed at this.

Pros:
- It's Minecraft, I'm a nerd
- There are various customisation options throughtout the game making you feel more involved
- The lanscapes and buildings are beautifully done (in Minecraft standards obviously)
- Endings are somehwhat suspensful
- Episode 5 did have some redeeming features
- I was kind of sad at certain stages, TellTale usually leaves me in a state of depression though (therefore also a Con)

Cons:
- Music becomes repetitive and annoying
- Graphical glitches that are easy to notice and fix
- Subtitle inconsistency
- Story blunders in relation to characters
- Choices have a minimum impact
- Low standard compared to previous TellTale titles
- Some sections of dialogue and story felt utterly meaningless
- Episode 5 was the intro to the DLC. This means that Minecraft Story mode was technically only 4 episodes long and episode 5 was just there to get us to buy the DLC

Gameplay - 6/10
Immersion - 6/10
Graphics - 6/10

Overall rating - 6/10

P.S. The reason this review is negative is because it does not live up to the usual quality of a TellTale game. I was highly dissapointed in it as it felt like nothing more than a rushed source of income paid out from Microsoft. Perhaps they will fix their mistakes in the DLC. Buy it if you want to but be warned if you are expecting a TellTale game, it's not.

reviewText:
In the beginning... I absolutely loved this game. It was my first telltale game ever, and I was quite a fan of minecraft. The promise was good... a 5 part episodic series that would tell the tale of the order of the stone. I really enjoyed the game... up until I finished episode 5...

The story that is being advertised, ends in episode 4, and the ENTIRITY of episode 5 is set-up/the beginning of the DLC.
Telltale promised us a 5 part episodic adventure, but the story we paid for, was finished in 4. Technically there could have been 20% more story, but now we got a lure/bait to buy the dlc.
I explained my feelings in regards to this sudden move in a video on my channel:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Snwb_EQrpwM

I bought the game, expecting a full story that would last 5 episodes. Not a story that might have been cut by 20%, only to make place for a DLC bait set-up. Sure... episode 6 seems like a good start to a new chapter of the story, but I didnt pay for it. All my feelings are explained in the video. Everyone is free to agree or disagree with it, and that is fine, but I absolutely feel, that with the arrival of the adventure pass, I was scammed.

For that reason... I would NOT recommend this game.

If something changes, maybe a refund worth of at least 1 episode for those who bought the game before this dlc (episode number 5) plus a change to the store page to indicate the story is only 4 episodes long... I might change my stance. But until that happens... NOT RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Many recent reviews criticise this game for its DLC practices, suggesting that the main story arc is unfinished forcing players to buy episodes to know the ending. This is not true; the base game contains two finished story arcs, and opens the Minecraft universe up for future self-contained story arcs through purchasable DLC.

Whilst the base game in my opinion, in places, is not as good as other games that use the Telltale Tool (game engine), overall it is stellar. I look forward to further exploring future Minecraft Story Mode releases.

Also for some reason the mouse does not always work then using keyboard to move the char. Just locks for a second (usualy when you need to react fast to point and click.

Update:After finishing the game twice there was almost no change to the outcome with the choices i made. I am however hoping that the choices you make will effect the outcome further in the game (episode 3  and up).
I realy liked wolf umong us and how the choices you took realy effect the game but with this game it looks like the devs have focused on younger people and they dont want to traumatize kids. Like if the butcher would have turned Reuben in to bacon if you would have not done anything ? or the creepers on the bridge would have blown you up if you attacked ? Get eaten by the ender monster if you tried to stay ? etc etc.

I realy hope that the next episode turn the game around or at least the story mode will be a story mode and not a linear one with no consequences to bad choices you make.
Until then my opinion on the game will stay as it is.

reviewText: This game is trying to be kiddish and dramatic at the same time. The end result is just awkward. You have a hard time taking the story seriously because you don't feel the tension while surrounded by the fun environment. At the same time you can't get into the the light-hearted parts (like the want for adventure, or the little silly bits) because the story is always trying to inject drama (fighting between teammates, and the fact that hundreds of people" are dying). There are many other problems too
hoursPlayed: and the flat characters.\n\nIf you were hoping this game was going to give you some awesome lore to go with an awesome game like minecraft well don't get your hopes up. Instead get ready to jump into a less fun version of the lego movie with some dark background themes."

reviewText:
WOW this game is so much better than I thought it would be, it´s not AMAZING but it´s not supposed to be.
Minecraft Story Mode is a point-and-click game (just to warn the kids about buying this game thinking that it's just like Minecraft).
The humor is more towards a younger audience, there are a lot of funny and/or clever jokes, but it's mostely juvenile.
The story (wich is 90% of the game, obviously) starts out as meh but getting better as the episodes go on.
The translation is ####, if you don't know english (hear english, to be exact) then good luck, somethings are badly translated confusing you in some situations and some words are not even translated.
I'm portuguese and 95% of episode 4's dialogue is in SPANISH.

In conclusion, Minecraft Story Mode it's a flawed but enjoyable adventure, and definitely worth buying (but wait until a discount or until episode 5 comes out).

(P.S: make sure you have a decent enough pc to run this game, if you don't your pc might just shut down while you are playing)

reviewText: I honestly expected so much more from this game...\nPersonally, I love Minecraft, I've played for nearly three years. So when I learned there was a story mode I was excited. I immediately went to the steam store and purchased the game. I launched the game with no prior knowledge of all the issues this game has. Firstly, the game has extremely long cutscenes, that you cannot skip, which is irretating. Secondly, the humor in this game seems to only be satisfying to the younger players, which was not amusing to me. Thirdly, I felt like the storyline was poorly put together almost as if it was thrown together as fast as it could have been so that it could be put on sale as soon as possible. One other issue I had with the game were the camera angles. Again, poor effort Telltale. Another major disappointment I had with this game was on episode four, part one, the game stopped working. The dialogue was not being queued by my movement. After the game stopped working properly I gave up, and just never touched the game again...I wish I saved my money.

reviewText:
OK, I bought this game sometime in March when Episodes 1-4 had been released, and Episode 5 was set for a March 29th release. Now, here is my review.

STORY

The game is based off the overwhelmingly popular sandbox game Minecraft created by Mojang in 2009, but I think you've guessed that by now! Minecraft has no pre-made story (you make your own) apart from travelling through a mystical portal to enter a spit of sand in space called the End. Inhabiting the End is a huge Ender Dragon that you have to kill to reach the credits scene. Telltale managed to take the story of this dragon and create a story that spanned over 4 episodes.

Many many years ago, a legendary group called The Order of the Stone journeyed across the Overworld, embarking on amazing quests. The Order was made up of Gabriel the Warrior, Ellegaard the Engineer, Magnus the Rogue and Soren the Architect and the leader. In their final and most famous quest, they ventured into the End and slayed the Ender Dragon. History turned to legend, legend turned to myth, and the members of the Order disappeared into the shadows.

But one stayed in the spotlight - Gabriel the Warrior. Now, you (Jesse, either male or female) and your friends Axel and Olivia, along with your pet pig Reuben, are off to visit Endercon, where Gabriel is said to be the special guest.

However, disaster strikes, and you and your companions must reunite the Order so that they can save the world by destroying the terrifying Wither Storm that threatens their very exsistence...

The Wither Storm story is set in 4 episodes:

Episode 1: The Order of the Stone
Episode 2: Assembly Required
Episode 3: The Last Place You Look
Episode 4: A Block and a Hard Place

In Episode 5, the story stands completely alone, as a sort of demo episode for the Adventure Pass, the DLC that includes Episodes 6-8. It's the same size as the other episodes, but it does feel a little weird because it's seperate from the other arc. In Episode 5: Order Up, the group travels to a strange new land via a magic portal. Order Up is the start of the new story arc (Episodes 5-8). Lots of people seem to be angry about the new DLC, saying that they believed they were buying a full season, not half. They have their season, but from my view Story Mode will never have a Season 2, because it will just keep expanding with new DLC episodes (a new story arc for every addon). If anyone post Episode 8 wants a review of the DLC (which I've already bought) I will be putting that in a seperate review on the store page for the Adventure Pass.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is like the many other Telltale games. You'll be choosing from four dialog options, and you'll have a short amount of time to choose how you react. Story Mode is a Point and Click game, where you'll have to solve puzzles. There's also a ton of Quick Time Events, and the decisions that you'll make will affect the story. Some decisions are small, and affect the next chapter, or the rest of the episode, but some span across whole episodes (one choice in Episode 1 creates a determinant character for Episode 2 and 3).

REPLAYABLITY

The choices you'll make will open up at least 2 different playthroughs, and if you want to choose every dialog option you'll have to do 4 playthroughs. To do Episode 5 in each suit of armour you would need to do 10 playthroughs. It would also take 6 playthroughs to play as all the different versions of Jesse, as there are three male (white skinned, olive skinned, dark skinned) and three female (white skinned, olive skinned, dark skinned). I am about 3/4 through my second playthrough of Story Mode Episodes 1-5 with olive skinned male Jesse and in my next playthrough I'll be playing as the dark skinned female Jesse so I can see how the voice actor for Female Jesse plays the character.

GRAPHICS

The graphics are the same as Minecraft, but they are more 3-D. They ran alright on max settings on my ancient computer, apart from in some action sequences. On a good computer, there should be absolutely no worries about lag.

OTHER

I think the PEGI 12 rating for Story Mode is a bit much. It says a few mild swears like c**p, but that is pretty much it. I let my two cousins (they are 7 and 9) play this on my computer where they decided what to say/do as a team. They'd heard it all before, and I'm sure that people about 8+ would be fine to play this.

VERDICT

This game is very fun, with some good acting, and the episodes are quite long. I think it's a good game to give younger kids a taste of 'Choice Matter' gameplay, as I haven't heard of many games like that for kids. They are missing out! It's still good for people that like Telltale or Minecraft too. If you like either Telltale or Minecraft, give this a try!

1) Essential Purchase
2)Recommended Purchase 3)Recommended during a sale
4)Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5)Not recommended even for hardcore Steam gamers

reviewText:
So, this game had so much potential. Not just because it was Minecraft, but because it was going to have a huge audience. Yes, I am a Minecraft player, and yes, there are a few bits of it that bug me when it comes to the Minecraft content, but that's not why I gave it a thumbs down.

I understand first episodes are going to be slow, and work as essentially the tutorial. However, as of this moment it feels like I'm watching a Slamacow animation and not actually playing a game. It feels like a storybook, not a game. Now I haven't played their other Walking Dead game (not my cup of tea, i'll stick to the comics), so maybe this is their style, However the way it was presented in multiple articles on multiple websites was a bit misleading.

To be honest, I expected a sort of... Life Is Strange feel. Open areas that you can explore with a few little secrets that can be tracked or just be there for fun. Instead it's a webcomic that we're making the speech options for the characters.

If the coming episodes change this (as I stated prior, maybe this is just the tutorial" episode to get the plot rolling and you get a hang of the controls)
date: then I'll definitely modify the review to fit it. If not

reviewText:
I'm usually a fan of games made by Tell-Tale Games, however this is a big disappointment.

The controls aren't smooth at all, and there is really no action as far as I am concerned. You basically walk for a few seconds, click some dialouge, and watch cut-scenes the whole time. I was very excited for the release of this game, however I feel that the game was rushed and if they would've waited a little longer, they would have realized how bad this game really is. If I wouldn't have kept playing, I would've asked for a refund but I played over 2 hours.


0/10 would purchase this game again.

reviewText:
I am not too familiar with other Telltale titles, nor was I hyping for this game, but I liked the idea and went ahead with it.

The game surely ISN'T impressive and life-changing, but it certainly isn't bad enough to receive THIS much hate. It's the moderate/good experience it is either because Telltale tried to add a few good elements but didn't bother to refine them, or because they limitted it with the intent of not overwhelming younger players.

Honestly, you know how Minecraft is about making up your own stories, (almost) failing, and trying to get better at it? That's what this feels like, and so the unimpressiveness is nice because of its familiarity. However, with all the potential Minecraft itself has, it deserves an actually mindblowing, highly interactive, rich and deep experience (which you definitely don't find in this story mode). Hopefully, that too will come along one day.

Pros
+ Lots of Minecraft lore and some humerous critiquing of it
+ Some interesting builds to explore
+ Branching story to make your decisions as the player count
+ You get to choose how to respond to the more unusual of developments
+ Feels like the Minecraft adventures you might go on with your friends (without the unnecessary delays obviously)
+ Adequate/good voice acting
+ Explores various emotional situations although without much depth

Cons
- No open-world stuff; just Interactive cutscenes or small maps to roam around in. Big disappointment.
- Characters aren't that deep.
- The lip-syncing - or whatever you might call it - gets annoying.
- The plot, although not so predictable and free of many loose ends, doesn't get quite thick.


Verdict: Give this game a chance, especially if you like Minecraft, but don't expect too much from it.

reviewText:
A slightly bizarre twist on a game that has built its name on being Sandbox!!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZXLpCbVjUJU

After playing this for a good 9 hours I can honestly say that this game is great fun as long as you don't get too caught up in the whole its not Minecraft" "Its not a sandbox game" debate.... Take it as it is. A Tell Tale story game based in the Minecraft universe.

My main criticism is the fact that it has been rated as 12... The only reason for this is the adult (Rude) words  dispersed throughout... In my humble opinion Tell Tale should have had a child option where the swear words are beeped out. Simples.

10/10 I would allow swearing in a Kids game again. :)"

reviewText:
This review is for people who have been deep in the minecraft community.

I myself have been playing minecraft since the beta and i think it is awesome to see this game.
If your another minecraft player, what's important to understand is that this is not anything like the minecraft game. It's not a sequel or even a sandbox. What is has to do with minecraft is its universe and its story telling ability.

I don't know if you are a guy whos strictly done survival, creative, minigames or adventure maps but this game is sort of like an adventure map, maybe with a little less interaction than a sandbox game offers, however, it focuses a lot more on the story. The most interaction takes place in driving the story. Based on the difference in choices, some one else could be playing maybe an entirely different game XD

If you do get the game, don't expect a mindblowing story with some crazy heavy morals to learn at the end or something. It isn't terrible but i mean, like animated movies you'd go to see in a theatre, everyone should be able to enjoy it, including young children.

So basically, if your interested in a interactive movie type game taking place in the world of minecraft, i suppose it's worth a shot.

I've never played a telltale game or any game like this before. I just knew it was minecraft. I tried it and i'm pretty satisfied with what the game has shown me so far.

Episode 2: Assembly Required

but I still enjoy it a lot.

reviewText: First of all I have to mention what this game isn't since too many people expect it to be this even though it didn't take much to find stuff telling you its not: Its not Minecraft. What it is is a game set in a Minecraft world which is like a game version of a Minecraft Novel version of one of those books where you get to decide what happens in the story by answering multiple choice questions. They don't always give you much time to answer and there is some button mashing involved but it is a lot of fun. It isn't some complex story like Agatha Christie novels. Its just a simple but fun story based on episode 1. The episodic nature of the delivery is a bit of a pain but its still fun & I am glad a bought it. My oldest son has really enjoyed it too.

reviewText:
Minecraft: Story Mode doesn’t feel like a Telltales game. It feels like a cash-in. It feels like Microsoft threw a big beefy contract at Telltales and said “Just do the usual”.

At first glance it may look like the usual fare: an impressive ensemble cast and a heavy lean on comedy but in actuality they've taken some big names, thrown them into a mixing bowl and hoped for the best.

Some of the Actors are dreadful and either don’t understand voice acting or have had terrible direction. The plot - or as much as I absorbed - isn’t very interesting.

reviewText:
Not looking at the Minecraft series while writing this review: Telltale generally makes great series games like TWD and GOT, however this one looks slapped together just for a quick money grab — from horible voice acting, a generic non essential choice storyline and even graphic and audio issue. Did they even test this game?
Minecraft is Minecraft: no story, open sandbox do what you want. Farm, mine, visit the nether or end... there isn't a meaning of what needs to be done. Making a game series with a story needs to hold us in for more than that. The first episode should have captivated our attention and made us really want to find out more — it was very dissapointing and lacking attention to that fact.

Game is set up for my 5 year old to play — seriously, thats basically who this game is for.

If you're a TTG fan and do not have children dont bother on this investment. It's a game for little kids and should have been console only.

reviewText:
I usually never review any games ever. However I was shocked at how awesome this game was. Coming from a minecraft player since about 2011, It's been my favorite game of all time. Early 2015 when I heard there was going to be another minecraft game, being made by Telltale. I was skeptical, but optimistic. Minecraft is such a huge game with a story that could go in an infiniate number of ways becauase it has no story. After the first Minecon trailer, I was still feeling the same thoughts on the game. But then the trailer for the first episode release, And that's when I wanted the game more than anything. It looked like it's own seperate entity but not in a bad way. This week I finally got to play it. Finally after 4 years of playing the game, I got a story to be the compainion to my favorite game. Initially, my thoughts we're scattered. I was a bit overwhelmed by the stories fast actions. When I finished the first episode. I thought I'd give it an 8/10. However, since then I've went back and played the game. And I was able to play different routes in the game and I was able to let the story sink in more. This is where the game really shines. I think the game could have more gameplay segments. Because there was rarley a time I got to control Jesse for more than 2 minutes. But that's what future episodes are for.

I also expirienced many bugs in the game, however I'm playing on a mac and the playthroughs of people I saw on the internet had none of the bugs I expirience. Nothing game breaking though.

Overall I give Minecraft Story Mode Episode 1 a score of 9/10. - Diffinately worth being In the same universe as my favorite game of all time.

reviewText:
Like a lot of people, I really dig TellTale's endeavours since The Walking Dead. This time around though I had to request a refund. The game is simply targeted at a much younger audience. Wait! - don't roll your eyes yet reader, it was obvious since the announcement of Story Mode that TellTale would have to change their usual formula and address the millions (billions?) of kids playing Minecraft. Regardless, I expected a game which all ages could enjoy, something along the lines of 'The Lego Movie'. Story Mode however felt like a saturday morning cartoon. Not a bad one I guess, it probably takes a lot of craft to make something enjoyable to kids. The difference is one is aimed 'solely' at kids whilst the other is not. The developers have no obligation to make a game for me, but considering TellTales 'ouvre' some consumer advice is warranted.

Granted, I played this game for less than an hour, so perhaps Story Mode turns around, but this is my general critique.

Everything in this game is very overt, leaving little room for subtlety. This is exceptionally jarring in the characterizations. You notice it in the voice acting almost immedately. The second one of your sullen companions opens his mouth you know exactely which thrope he falls into (big, heart of gold, shy, etc). Incidentely, I stopped playing at the part where your group has to get past a big bouncer who is inexplicately afraid of chickens. This is shown by him cowering in front of a chicken exclaiming his particular phobia all the whilst the camera pans and shows a towering chicken contraption a meter away in the background (Puzzle time!). Not claiming the Tales of the Borderlands was subtle, but that scene was just inane. I can go one listing all the one-dimensional characters but you can watch the trailer and pretty much figure it out from there.

Now, normally you'd think there would be some humor thrown in to please the more adult adience. That didn't happen. There were plenty of opportunities to lampshade certain aspects of Minecraft. The remaining humor is very safe and kids friendly (e.g. a big person gets stuck in a fence for a bit).

This wouldn't all be bad if at least the plot went in interesting places. This could still very well be the case, but judging from what I've seen I am not willing to bet 22.99 on it. All the high notes are being foreshadowed pretty heavily.

Returning to the first paragraph, I am not claiming this is a bad game, just not one fans of TellTale can blindlessly purchase. If you must, please keep tabs on the clock so you don't forfeit the chance to refund this.

reviewText:
This game is not amazingly well written. The plot isn't ambitious and combat is boring as hell.

But if you're a Minecraft fan, you'll find yourself an experience crafted with surprising amount of care and love put into it.
It is very obvious that the creators of the game spend a lot of time playing it and put effort into understanding it's culture.
It's not just obvious jokes like punching wood with your fists. The game will very often nod to less recognizable but still strong and influential concepts you may know from playing survival for a long time.


On a Minecon 2015 panel, Telltale writes claimed while playing you'll meet various types of Minecraft players. It might seem like they're talking about the very obvious stereotypes of Griefer, Builder, Redstoner, Fighter who are the important characters to the story, but if you spend some time exploring the world, you actually find much more diverse
people whose interests you might even identify with!

-GAMEPLAY-

While the choices in the game don't matter to the main plot at all like in all Telltale games,  this game makes them feel more like actual gameplay.
You will find yourself juggling friendships, saving the world and trying not to offend your little piglet.  The game is aware you know exactly how the story is going to end, but lets you choose who you'll take to that happy end. It will test your trust in your friends, the feeling of responsibility vs how much you care about showing someone you appreciate them.

This is where the game exels at and as long as you are able to enjoy the characters it throws at you, you'll be in for a fun ride.


All in all, this game is a pure fan service story about adventuring with your friends. It does well what it sets out to do, but seems to be fit for a niche demographic.  If you never played Minecraft, don't touch it. If you've been in the community for at least a year, you'll have plenty of fun with it.

reviewText:
I have to admit, I didn't expect this to be what it was at all.  And after the first couple of minutes, I really came to love this title.

Every decision you have to make has a time limit, and you have to weigh it all, because there's always that chance that the decision you're making is truly important.  Some of the decisions must be made in the middle of an action sequence, and I think that's where this game shines: a reflexive action can have consequences, and I'm not used to seeing that play out in games at all.

The game does a great job of balancing when you can control your character, as well as when quick time events, or other segments when you have very little time to perform an action, pop up.  This meant that I was always engaged in what was going on, and the timed nature of certain elements makes sure the game keeps flowing; if you're one of those people who is used to battling out the consequences of a single action (like me when I'm playing Tactics Ogre) before making a decision, this game forces you to go against that mindset, and keeps you on your toes.

I have to say, the way that the game's areas are planned out is really clever; there's always a general pathway that you take, but it keeps things moving instead of bottlenecking the pace, and really drives the narrative.  The only hiccup I found involved a sequence where you had to pull some levers, and the clicks didn't always select the lever I was clicking on.  Other than this one flaw, I can't think of anything I don't like about the game.

The first episode delivered a lot of satisfying content, and I was hopelessly attached to the main character's trusty pig companion.  It's elements like the pig, the camaraderie between the main group, and just the general way the characters in the world acted that brought me back to those older movies that made me feel great when I was a kid.  It has that charm, but it's all delivered in a way that both adults and younger audiences alike can thoroughly enjoy.

I haven't played a game this heartwarming or exciting in a long time, and I really can't wait to see what the future has to offer.  If you decide to buy this, I hope you find as much enjoyment out of it as I did.

reviewText:
I must admit, I was skeptical when I saw this game come out. But, Telltale Games has a good rep and it  was  minecraft, so I got the game.

And I was blown away.

My only complaint is the eating animation, that could have used a lot more work.

Aside from that, the story is unique and phenominally written, the choices you make come up in some of the most unexpected places, the animation looks and feels like minecraft, and the characters are unique, developed, and fun. I cannot wait for the next chapter.
Big piece of advice to new players: Make decisions quickly and carefully, and experiment when you have plenty of time. You never know what will happen when you take an extra look around or your choice goes awry.

reviewText:
I must admit, I was skeptical when I saw this game come out. But, Telltale Games has a good rep and it  was  minecraft, so I got the game.

And I was blown away.

My only complaint is the eating animation, that could have used a lot more work.

Aside from that, the story is unique and phenominally written, the choices you make come up in some of the most unexpected places, the animation looks and feels like minecraft, and the characters are unique, developed, and fun. I cannot wait for the next chapter.
Big piece of advice to new players: Make decisions quickly and carefully, and experiment when you have plenty of time. You never know what will happen when you take an extra look around or your choice goes awry.

reviewText:
This game puts in the role of Jesse (man/woman) who is trying to save the world from a massive monster called the Witherstorm. You have to make decisions that will decide your fate in the end game. This game may get emotional because (spoiler alert) Petra may die. This game will keep you on edge and it has humor even adults would enjoy. Minecraft Story Mode: Episode 1 was and intro to the plot, Witherstorm is about to eradicate all humanity, start to know the characters in the story, and have lots of quick time events. Minecraft Story Mode: Episode 2 focused on finding either 2 members of the Order of the Stone. You either go to Redstonia or Boomtown which each have distinctive features that stick out. You end up at the base of the missing member known as Soren, but an evil member (Ivor) is on his way there. You get there to find out Petra is sick with the Wither. You find Ivor and have a battle with him, you lose and he escapes.

So far this story has some holes, but hopefully it will be filled in the next episode.
9/10
P.S. Rueben is the best character in the entire game

reviewText:
Ok

To start off this game looked good in the trailer, and yes it did deliver
The first episode was, then it dragged into a complete mess of a game


This game was exteremely rushed and the plot went knowwhere
The characters are unrelatable
The ending for episode 5 where they killed the main monster was bad

In this game, when characters die, you dont feel bad at all
your ment to feel sad but you dont!


Episode 2 was alright but definitely didn't beat episode one
Episode 3 felt clunky and just didn't appeal to me
The plot isn't that good either to be completely honest
And after playing episode 4 I stopped playing, nothing could save it at this point

To put it short, Telltale, you ♥♥♥♥ed up bad.

reviewText:
Minecraft is amazing. Telltale's games are amazing. Put both of them together? Not good at all.

Minecraft: Story Mode looked awesome when I first saw it, and it looked like it'd be a great game. Episode 1, however, got real boring extremely quickly. Most of the voice actors are either crap or just don't care, the writing is cheesy and not really funny, and the story is just meh.

Needless to say, I got a refund on this game and will be sticking to just watching videos when the other episodes come out. If you're a huge fan of Minecraft and Telltale Games, just watch some videos of this, because buying the game itself is just not worth it.

reviewText:
Ok so this is BARE BONES!
- Only 3 episodes long with ep 4 on the way and ep 5 is looking like DLC.
- Lip Sync gets off a lot
- Dialog gets cut off from time to time( Turn on Subtitles so you don't miss anything!)
- Super short! You will finish in 4 or less hours!
- Not a whole lot of actual gameplay.
- Super easy, they tell you everything and leaves no real challenge.
- $10-$15 title price at the most, DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE!
- Way to easy, hardley any sort of challenge.
- A lot of the time your desicions on things don't matter at all out come or dialog whise.

+ Great with keeping the look of Minecraft while adding a bit more detail.
+ Good voice actors, could be a bit better, but still good.
+ Good story
+ Most of the characters you'll care about, but some you won't.

reviewText: Boring button mashing game.  I was epxecting this to be an actual story mode to minecraft, not a linear scripted indigo prophecy type game with minecraft graphics.  I really was hoping to learn how to better use recipes while building structures to solve puzzles and fight different creatures with normal minecraft controls.  I only finished episode 1, but based on other reviews it doesn't seem to change.  The story is boring, the game stutters frequently, and the controls (when you are actually controlling the characer which is 3% of the time) are clunky and basically are just using wasd from an odd angle, or point and clicking.  Very dissapointed here, this game could have been so much more.  Would love to see an actual minecraft story mode where you started out with basic recipes and built up from there.  Maybe a minecraft rpg.

reviewText:
Minecraft: Story Mode has a charming yet deep storyline, steeped in Minecraftiness and with plenty of light-hearted moments. It is probably more of a children's game than a dark, gritty tale of darkness and grittiness, but don't let that fool you into thinking it's a bland, overly-heartwarming pile of cute little bunny rabbits and the Power of Friendship. There are dark moments, even the deaths of a major character or two, as well as a couple of jokes only older players are likely to understand.

The gameplay is pretty simple, more like an interactive film than most games. I should point out that it's not at all like playing Minecraft. You can't freely place and break blocks, nor do much in the way of actual mining and crafting. Occasional quick-time events keep the player on their toes; these are pretty challenging, but you can generally try again if you fail something important.

The game has plenty of feminism, too; competent women who wear sensible clothes and take an active role in fighting the antagonists are everywhere. Gameplay is completely unaffected by the player character's sex and skin colour.

That's not to say the game is without flaws. Gameplay sometimes consists of a long string of cutscenes, which, if you prefer a fast-paced action game, will likely bore you to tears. The choices you make don't have that big an effect on how the story pans out; there is definitely some effect, but however you play the game, the same overarching events are guaranteed to happen. Also, way the characters are animated can be a little uncanny.

All in all, Minecraft: Story Mode is a pretty good story game. It's not necessarily a brilliant, challenging action-adventure game, nor is it Telltale Games' finest work, nor is it like playing a Minecraft adventure map. Still, if you like the lore of Minecraft and have a decent sense of humour, you'll probably enjoy it.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of Minecraft, then you will love this game. It hooks you in and you don't want to stop playing.It has all the spirit of Minecraft. The world, the mechanics, all wrapped around an excellent story. There are a few things I need to address though.

-Options menu:
The options menu is really weird in this game. There is no button to apply the settings. You have to go back to the main menu to apply them.

-The cringe:
There are quite a few cringe moments in this game. Not enough to stop you from playing, so keep this in mind.

-Mouth animations:
I shouldn't fault them on this, but I thought I would point it out anyway. The mouth animations are really awkward. Sometimes when characters stop talking, they will just smile for no reason. It makes for very awkward moments.

reviewText:
A true masterpiece and an another success of Telltale Games, that created a incredible story inside one of the most biggest online games.
It's true that sometimes the waiting for the next episode is such painful but it's completely worth of it.
It was originally planned for a 5 episodes story, but when the Wither Storm Story ended on episode 4, Telltale did a tricky idea making a start of a new story on Episode 5, leaving to us the waiting of three new episodes in order to continue the story.
Such a shame that some of the beloved characters like Reuben die during our long journey...

reviewText: The story is a lot deeper than people are giving it credit for. It does a great job of making the player feel like they're dealing with a truly daunting and unknown menace. Telltale's game engine has clearly taken on significant improvements from previous games. No glitches or bugs to be seen, and most of the bad reviews are comments on the release strategy, which is not what the steam review system is for. As a further comment on the release strategy, Telltale wanted to do a 8-episode story, since most of their games are 5 episodes, had they released them all at once the price wouldve been 40$ which people would've complained about just as much. At least this way people get to make the decision themselves.\n\nThe game is far from incomplete without the DLC, the story through the first episodes is perfectly resolved without it.
